practice_instances.text: Appropriate guidelines are required for devising quality assessment strategies.
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: The possible differences between SLR and SMS could offer advice when researchers perform quality assessment in SLR and SMS.
practice_instances.code: SLR/SMS guidelines to perform QA evaluation
practice_instances.practice_instance: Consider differences between SLR and SMS when conducting quality assessment.

practice_instances.text: For each aspect, researchers can gain the knowledge of the most concerned criteria, which is particularly helpful in developing and applying quality assessment instruments for future SLRs.
practice_instances.code: Use common criteria for QA evaluation
practice_instances.practice_instance: Identify and use key criteria to develop and apply quality assessment instruments for future SLRs.

practice_instances.text: Systematic reviewers can form their own quality assessment checklists by selecting and revising several questions from the original questions.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Develop customized quality assessment checklists by adapting existing questions.

practice_instances.text: GRADE is a complicated approach and may be difficult for new SLR researchers.
practice_instances.practice_instance: GRADE is not recommended for new researchers

practice_instances.text: If there exist any former SLRs on the similar topic, researchers may consult these SLRs in developing their criteria for quality assessment.
practice_instances.code: Consult similar SLRs to develop yours
practice_instances.practice_instance: Consult prior SLRs on similar topics to inform quality assessment criteria.

practice_instances.text: Our review has also found that there are not many SLRs whose quality assessment criteria pay sufficient attention to the credibility aspect in their quality assessment criteria.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Incorporate credibility aspects into quality assessment criteria.

practice_instances.text: This situation might ignore the negative effect of the factors like inconsistency of results that could make to the strength of the evidence.
practice_instances.code: Consider the negative effects of inconsistency of results
practice_instances.practice_instance: Account for negative factors such as result inconsistency in evidence strength.

practice_instances.text: We assigned the workload to make sure that each study was checked by at least two researchers independently to minimize the potential impact of any bias.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Perform independent review check by at least two researchers to reduce bias.

practice_instances.text: The disagreements on search and selection opinions were solved in joint discussion.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Resolve disagreements on search and selection through joint discussion.

practice_instances.text: Any disagreements that could not be solved were escalated to the supervisor.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Escalate unresolved disagreements to a supervisor.

practice_instances.text: Hence, it is important that SLRs researchers start paying more attention to the quality assessment of the papers included in SLRs.
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Albeit quality assessment is not recommended for SMS, this part could be a good choice to increase the credibility of evidence in an SMS.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Consider applying quality assessment in SMS to increase credibility.

practice_instances.text: Moreover, the cross-check was necessary among the reviewers, and again we had at least two research students extracting data from each selected SLR independently.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Perform independent cross-checks with multiple reviewers for data extraction.

practice_instances.text: The supervisor played the role of expert panel who dealt with any divergences and disagreements between the students during the process.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use supervisors or expert panels to resolve reviewer divergences.

practice_instances.text: This information can help researchers to develop the quality criteria according to the purpose of their quality assessment: rather than ‘blindly’ performing the quality assessment for no particular reason.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Develop quality criteria aligned with assessment purpose, not blindly.

practice_instances.text: Are the metrics (methods, design, measures) used in the study clearly (fully) defined (description)?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Define study metrics, methods, and measures.

practice_instances.text: Are the variables/metrics/methods/design used in the study adequately measured and validated (justified)?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Validate and justify variables, metrics, and study design.

practice_instances.text: Was the data analysis (collected) sufficiently rigorous?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Conduct data analysis rigorously.

practice_instances.text: Was there a control group with which to compare treatments?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use control groups where applicable.

practice_instances.text: Was the research design appropriate to address the aims of the research?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Is the methodology (design) used suitable to address the stated research questions?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use methodology suitable for the research questions.

practice_instances.text: Has the relationship between researcher and participants been considered to an adequate degree?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Consider researcher–participant relationship adequately.

practice_instances.text: Do the researchers discuss any problems (limitations, threats) with the validity (reliability) of their results?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Discuss limitations and threats to validity.

practice_instances.text: Are the findings credible?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Based on our observation, we suggest that researchers should care more about the aspect of credibility, which directly impacts the validity and generalizability of a study’s conclusion.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Prioritize credibility to strengthen validity and generalizability.

practice_instances.text: "Additional sources of bias across studies, such as failing to locate appropriate reports to include and the effects of financial conflicts of interest, should be evaluated as part of the review process;"
practice_instances.practice_instance: Evaluate and report additional sources of bias across studies.

practice_instances.text: "this category of bias can often be minimized by utilizing a well-designed review protocol (Miller 2000)."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Minimize bias by using well-designed review protocols.

practice_instances.text: "The funding source for the review should be disclosed in publication to allow the reader to evaluate potential bias from conflicts of interest."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Disclose funding sources to assess potential conflicts of interest.

practice_instances.text: "In order to assist the reader in appropriate interpretation of the review results it is important to highlight and discuss limitations in any review publication."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Highlight and discuss limitations in review publications.

practice_instances.text: "it is helpful for the authors to discuss where their findings likely can and cannot be applied based on the scope of the review."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Discuss applicability and limits of findings.

practice_instances.text: "We also recommend an assessment of bias both for each study included in the review and across the entire review."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Assess bias at both study and review levels.

practice_instances.text: "Bias based on methodology does not necessarily invalidate a study, but it is important to report and understand in order to optimize appro-priate interpretation of the study."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Report and interpret methodological bias rather than dismissing studies.

practice_instances.text: "We also recommend that authors specifically highlight the lim-itations of the systematic review as a way to assist the reader in result interpretation and highlight important questions for future research."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Highlight systematic review limitations to guide interpretation and future research.

practice_instances.text: Is there a clear statement (definition) of the aims (goals, purposes, problems, motivations, objectives, questions) of the research?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Does the study answer the research question defined or presents the results in a clear way?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Ensure the study answers the research question clearly.

practice_instances.text: Are the metrics used in the study the most relevant ones for answering the research questions?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use metrics that are relevant to anwer the research questions.

practice_instances.text: Is there a clear statement of findings (data) and relate to the aims of research?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Clearly state findings and relate them to research aims.

practice_instances.text: Is there an adequate description of the context in which the research was carried out?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Is the paper based on research?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Provide basis for the paper on actual research.

practice_instances.text: Are the data collection methods adequately described (defined)?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Describe data collection methods.

practice_instances.text: Are references maintained accurately?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Maintain references accurately.

practice_instances.text: Is the study replicable?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Was the data collected in a way that addressed the research issue?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Collect data in a way that addresses the research issue.

practice_instances.text: Has sufficient data been presented to support the findings?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: "We propose a checklist for a standardized technique for assessing and reporting reviews of LCA data (STARR-LCA) to assist in structuring the process of conduct-ing and reporting systematic reviews."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use a standardized checklist (e.g., STARR-LCA) to structure SLR assessment and reporting.

practice_instances.text: "We suggest that abstracts for systematic reviews related to LCA include at least the following nine components: (1) background; (2) objectives; (3) data sources; (4) study eligibility criteria; (5) scope, system boundaries and functional unit; (6) study appraisal and synthe-sis methods (including any original data adjustments, such as harmonization); (7) results; (8) limitations; and (9) conclusions with implications of key findings."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Include standardized components in abstracts of systematic reviews.

practice_instances.text: "In the context of what is already known, describe why the systematic review, with or without meta-analysis, was a worth-while effort."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Justify the systematic review in context of existing knowledge.

practice_instances.text: "A clear outline of the steps undertaken in a review can provide the transparency needed for replication, as well as ap-propriate updates when additional data are generated in fu-ture studies."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Provide clear outlines of review steps to ensure transparency and replication.

practice_instances.text: "We recommend that, at a minimum, a systematic review protocol include five key components: (1) a general description of how studies or data will be discovered for con-sideration of further review (e.g., literature or database search, manual review of the bibliographies of key publications, pre-vious studies performed by the author’s laboratory, solicitation of unpublished data); (2) enough information about any elec-tronic search strategies that the search can be replicated; (3) clear parameters describing how the decision will be made to in-clude or exclude individual studies and data for further analysis in the systematic review and/or meta-analysis; (4) a clear plan for recording and summarizing data from the individual studies, including what parameters or data points are of interest; and (5) what, if any, meta-analyses are planned."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Include key components in systematic review protocols to ensure replicability and rigor.

practice_instances.text: "Any revisions should be outlined and commented upon in subsequent publications and the protocol described should be transparent and complete enough to allow for replication."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Document and report protocol revisions transparently for replication.

practice_instances.text: "key information about the individual studies or sources of data included in the review should be provided."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Provide key information on all included studies or data sources.

practice_instances.text: "Whatever synthesis meth-ods are undertaken in a review, they should be clearly described and justified based on the study protocol and the available data included in the review."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Clearly describe and justify synthesis methods used.

practice_instances.text: "Article titles should clearly identify the manuscript as a review with or without meta-analysis, and key-word listings for both individual reports and database structure should include the terms meta-analysis and systematic review."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Clearly identify reviews in titles and keywords.

practice_instances.text: "A structured summary or abstract should be provided at the beginning of a review;"
practice_instances.practice_instance: Provide a structured abstract for reviews.

practice_instances.text: "The reason for the systematic review should be clear in the context of what is already known."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Clearly state the rationale for the review.

practice_instances.text: "A systematic review pro-tocol should be prospectively written to guide researchers and, ideally, made available for peer review with key areas as noted above."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Prospectively write and share systematic review protocols for peer review.

practice_instances.text: "We recommend that, in the interest of transparency, methods be clearly described and any new data presented as part of the publication."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Ensure transparency by clearly describing methods and presenting new data.

practice_instances.text: "Finally, the conclusions of the review should be clearly stated."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Clearly state the conclusions of the review.

practice_instances.text: Was the recruitment strategy appropriate to the aims of the research?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: In order to exhaustively identify SLRs with quality assessment component and ensure that the process of papers selection was unbiased as far as possible, the approach of quasi-gold standard (QGS) was adopted, which systematically integrates manual and automated search strategies and suggests a relatively rigorous approach for search performance evaluation in terms of sensitivity and precision.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use quasi-gold standard (QGS) integrating manual and automated searches to ensure unbiased and rigorous selection.

practice_instances.text: ...we also used the snowballing as the complementary search to reduce the possibility of missing relevant SLRs.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Apply snowballing as a complementary search to avoid missing relevant studies.

practice_instances.text: In addition, the search strategy was developed by the three research students and reviewed by their supervisor.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Develop search strategies collaboratively and review them with a supervisor.

practice_instances.text: To ensure the removal of these duplicates, each retrieved paper was checked and further read by at least two researchers independently to handle the duplication and limited bias as much as possible.
practice_instances.practice_instance: Check duplicates independently by at least two researchers to minimize bias.

practice_instances.text: Is the study of value for research or practice?
practice_instances.practice_instance: nan

practice_instances.text: Are conclusions, implications for practice and future research, reported suitably for its audience?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Report conclusions and implications appropriately for the audience.

practice_instances.text: Has the approach been validated on a certain scale (either in academia or/ and industry)?
practice_instances.practice_instance: Validate the approach in academia or industry.

practice_instances.text: "In the context of current knowledge, explain how the review may add to the knowledge base of readers from a variety of backgrounds or disciplines."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Explain how the review contributes to the broader knowledge base.

practice_instances.text: "Based on PICO, we introduce a recommended question format, PIFT, related to LCA that includes definition of the product or process category being assessed, the impacts of inter-est, the flows or economic sectors contributing to the impact, and the types of LCA of interest."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use structured formats (e.g., PIFT) to define review questions.

practice_instances.text: "We recommend this structured question format for systematic reviews; however, it can also guide other review types or studies."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Apply structured question formats to guide reviews.

practice_instances.text: "Assisting the reader in understanding the important data, flaws, and strengths of the individual studies is key to a robust and use-ful review and provides context for the reader that facilitates appropriate application of the review study results."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Highlight data, strengths, and flaws of individual studies to aid interpretation.

practice_instances.text: "Limitations are also generally an excellent opportunity to highlight important questions for further research."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Use limitations to highlight future research directions.

practice_instances.text: "Specific points relative to prac-tical problem solving or setting policy may be especially useful to highlight."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Highlight practical or policy-relevant points in findings.

practice_instances.text: "we advise that protocols for systematic reviews in LCA and any associated meta-analysis methods be trialed for usability by the study group, reviewed, discussed, and revised as indicated during the course of the review."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Pilot, review, and refine protocols for usability and rigor.

practice_instances.text: "An answerable question should be the foundation for a review—and while question articulation can be an iterative process, a focused question should be drafted at the start of the systematic review process."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Formulate a focused, answerable review question at the start.

practice_instances.text: "Detection and minimization of bias in LCA is a new concept worthy of ongoing discussion."
practice_instances.practice_instance: Promote ongoing discussion on bias detection and minimization in LCA.
